title-group.article-title: Surv‚ÄêCRM‚Äê12: A Bayesian phase I/II survival CRM for right‚Äêcensored toxicity endpoints with competing disease progression
title-group.alt-title: Surv‚ÄêCRM‚Äê12: A Bayesian phase I/II survival CRM for right‚Äêcensored toxicity endpoints with competing disease progression

Mailman School of Public Health, Columbia University

license.license-p: This is an open access article under the terms of the http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ License, which permits use and distribution in any medium, provided the original work is properly cited, the use is non‚Äêcommercial and no modifications or adaptations are made.

abstract.p: The growing interest in new classes of anti‚Äêcancer agents, such as molecularly‚Äêtargeted therapies and immunotherapies with modes of action different from those of cytotoxic chemotherapies, has changed the dose‚Äêfinding paradigm. In this setting, the observation of late‚Äêonset toxicity endpoints may be precluded by treatment and trial discontinuation due to disease progression, defining a competing event to toxicity. Trial designs where dose‚Äêfinding is modeled in the framework of a survival competing risks model appear particularly well‚Äêsuited. We aim to provide a phase I/II dose‚Äêfinding design that allows dose‚Äêlimiting toxicity (DLT) outcomes to be delayed or unobserved due to competing progression within the possibly long observation window. The proposed design named the Survival‚Äêcontinual reassessment method‚Äê12, uses survival models for right‚Äêcensored DLT and progression endpoints. In this competing risks framework, cause‚Äêspecific hazards for DLT and progression‚Äêfree of DLT were considered, with model parameters estimated using Bayesian inference. It aims to identify the optimal dose (OD), by minimizing the cumulative incidence of disease progression, given an acceptable toxicity threshold. In a simulation study, design operating characteristics were evaluated and compared to the TITE‚ÄêBOIN‚ÄêET design and a nonparametric benchmark approach. The performance of the proposed method was consistent with the complexity of scenarios as assessed by the nonparametric benchmark. We found that the proposed design presents satisfying operating characteristics in selecting the OD and safety.

institution-wrap.institution: National Center for Advancing Translational Sciences

p.mixed-citation: AndrillonA, ChevretS, LeeSM, BiardL. Surv‚ÄêCRM‚Äê12: A Bayesian phase I/II survival CRM for right‚Äêcensored toxicity endpoints with competing disease progression. Statistics in Medicine. 2022;41(29):5753‚Äê5766. doi:10.1002/sim.9591 36259523

fn.p: Funding information National Center for Advancing Translational Sciences, UL1TR001873

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Historically, phase I cancer dose‚Äêfinding clinical trial designs were developed for cytotoxic drugs and aimed at defining the maximal tolerated dose (MTD) of a new drug from a small and finite set of fixed dose levels; in this setting, the outcome is commonly measured by the occurrence of dose‚Äêlimiting toxicities (DLT) over a short period of time. This paradigm has been challenged with the arrival of new classes of anticancer agents, such as molecularly‚Äêtargeted therapies (MTAs) and immunotherapies. Their modes of action target the immune system or tumor specific pathways and differ from those of cytotoxic chemotherapies. In contrast to cytotoxic chemotherapies, which are administrated at discrete time points and may cause acute severe toxicities, new agents may be responsible for late‚Äêonset toxicities, related to their pharmacological properties or prolonged and continuous administration.1, 2, 3 To handle such prolonged observation windows of toxicities,4 a number of model‚Äêbased designs have been proposed. Cheung and Chappell,5 introduced the time‚Äêto‚Äêevent continual reassessment method (TITE‚ÄêCRM), followed by Braun,6 Yuan and Yin,7 and Liu et al.8 Model‚Äêassisted designs have been also developed to provide solution for phase I trials with late‚Äêonset toxicity. Yuan et al9 proposed the Time‚Äêto‚Äêevent Bayesian optimal interval design (TITE‚ÄêBOIN) based on the single mean imputation method, while Lin and Yuan10 formulated a general methodology to allow model‚Äêassisted trial designs to accommodate pending DLT data.

With prolonged observation windows, competing events observed during the trial, such as disease progressions or death, may also occur, resulting in early treatment or study discontinuation. Toxicity assessment may be precluded by such early terminations of the patient exposure to the drug. Usually, the occurrence of a progression followed by the trial discontinuation within the toxicity window results either in patient replacement leading to increased study duration and cost, or implementation of practical strategies to handle those partial observations.11 However, considering progression as an independent censoring event ignores this information related to efficacy, and may impact the operating characteristics of the design, with decreased performances in selecting the correct dose.11 Accounting for any discontinuation event as informative censoring, using the cumulative incidence of DLT in a survival CRM setting improved the design operating characteristics compared to the binomial TITE‚ÄêCRM.12 The information provided by efficacy‚Äêrelated outcomes, such as disease progression, could be also used in the process of selecting a dose, resulting in phase I/II trial designs.13, 14, 15, 16, 17, 18, 19, 20 However, most of these phase I/II designs treat toxicity and efficacy as binary outcomes observed within the timeframe of the trial. Some addressed the issue of late‚Äêonset outcomes in phase I/II, assuming independent toxicity and efficacy outcomes.16, 21, 22 Nevertheless, patients who experience toxicity generally have their dose reduced or discontinued and are inconsistently followed for efficacy or progression. Therefore, the occurrences of progression and DLT compete with each other.

In this particular setting of phase I/II with delayed outcomes, Takeda et al22 proposed a Time‚Äêto‚Äêevent Bayesian optimal interval design (TITE‚ÄêBOIN‚ÄêET) to identify the optimal dose (OD), allowing staggered patient accrual by relaxing the need for complete follow‚Äêup of previously included patients. They applied the likelihood approach with pending toxicity data proposed by Lin and Yuan for both efficacy and toxicity outcomes.10 Allowing the continuous enrollment of new patients, when previous patients are still under observation, can shorten the duration of the trial, which is suitable for prolonged observation windows and late‚Äêonset toxicities. However, although the TITE‚ÄêBOIN‚ÄêET handles incomplete observations, it relies on binary endpoints for toxicity and efficacy, as stated above. Owing to the competing risks setting, a comprehensive method that formally includes the information of time‚Äêto‚Äêtoxicity and time‚Äêto‚Äêprogression using a survival working model for right‚Äêcensored endpoints, thus allowing the toxicity outcomes to be delayed or unobserved due to competing events within the observation window, appears fully appropriate for new anti‚Äêcancer agents. In this setting, Biard et al recently developed the CR‚ÄêCRM, a seamless phase I/II design for novel anti‚Äêcancer agents with competing disease progressions,23 using a survival likelihood framework with three stages: first rule‚Äêbased initiation, second toxicity‚Äêcentered escalation, and third toxicity and efficacy optimization. The CR‚ÄêCRM relies on a cause‚Äêspecific approach targeting the marginal latent incidences of events (toxicity and progression) for dose finding, close to a hypothetical situation where the time‚Äêto‚Äêtoxicity can be observed in the absence of failure due to progression,24 which may be hard to estimate in practice.

In this article, we develop a novel Bayesian Survival‚Äêcontinual reassessment method for phase I/II dose‚Äêfinding trials, named the Survival‚ÄêCRM‚Äê12 (Surv‚ÄêCRM‚Äê12), using survival models for right‚Äêcensored and competing DLT and progression endpoints: it allows the outcomes to be delayed or unobserved within the observation window. The proposed method aims to identify the OD, by minimizing the cumulative incidence of disease progression, given an acceptable toxicity threshold. With a single stage design, the Surv‚ÄêCRM‚Äê12 design is easier to implement and allows for the use of both toxicity and efficacy information for the entire trial. The Surv‚ÄêCRM‚Äê12 also targets the cumulative probability of events within the observation window, taking competing risks into account. It corresponds to an approach based on the observed patient outcomes, accounting for all competing events in dose finding and clinical decision making.

sec.title: MOTIVATING EXAMPLE
sec.p: The present work was retrospectively motivated by a phase I/II clinical trial setting in patients with low‚Äêrisk myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) to evaluate the tolerance and efficacy of a new targeted therapy combined with erythropoietin (EPO). More specifically, the goal of the trial was to determine the OD level of this targeted therapy in terms of both toxicity and efficacy, with constant dose of EPO. Outcomes were assessed after the first treatment cycle, up to 42 days. The DLT was defined as any grade ‚â•3 drug‚Äêrelated adverse event lasting more than 7 days, or any persisting cytopenias at day 42 without evidence of disease progression in bone marrow and/or peripheral blood. Treatment response was defined at day 21 by an increase in hemoglobin level of 1.5 g/dL or above. Progression free survival (PFS) was a secondary endpoint. The dose‚Äêfinding was scheduled to use the TITE‚ÄêBOIN‚ÄêET design,22 accounting for possible continuous recruitment during the 42‚Äêdays observation window for DLT. However, we wondered whether using a survival model to make full use of the DLT and PFS, defined as right‚Äêcensored competing risks outcomes, would be more informative in this setting.

sec.title: Problem formulation
sec.p: We consider a dose‚Äêfinding clinical trial where patients are followed up for DLT within an observation window [0,t‚àó], with the additional issue of a non negligible risk of treatment discontinuation due to disease progression, that precludes the complete and reliable assessment of DLT. In this time‚Äêto‚Äêevent framework in oncology, data are collected as dates and t‚àó is defined in days, resulting in t‚àó>1. During the trial, an aggravation of the patient status may occur, related to the progression of the malignancy, leading to treatment discontinuation in order to propose alternative therapies, if available. Similarly, patients who experience toxicity are generally dose reduced or discontinued and are inconsistently followed for efficacy or progression. In this setting, DLT and progression are competing events within [0,t‚àó], since both result in trial or treatment discontinuation. Consequently, by time t‚àó, patient can experience one of these three outcomes within the trial: ‚ÄúDLT,‚Äù ‚Äúdisease progression,‚Äù and ‚Äúneither DLT nor progression.‚Äù Death is considered as a DLT if related to the toxicity and as progression otherwise. Note that we assume no other cause of treatment discontinuation, and no censoring due to lost to follow‚Äêup, since it is unlikely in a oncology dose‚Äêfinding trial, where patients are usually closely followed and in advanced stages of their disease.

Let N, be the maximum sample size of the trial, ùíü={d1,‚Ä¶,dJ} the set of J doses of the new drug investigated in the trial. The goal of our proposed design is to identify a dose that optimizes the efficacy outcome, among tolerable doses. First, we define the set of tolerable doses, ùíú, as those dose levels at or below the MTD, defined as the dose with toxicity probability, p1j closest to the target œÄDLT. (1)ùíú={dj‚ààùíü:dj‚â§argmindj‚ààùíü|p1j‚àíœÄDLT|}. Then, we incorporate information on time‚Äêto‚Äêprogression to identify the ‚Äúoptimal‚Äù dose (OD), dŒΩ. We define the OD as the dose level(s) with minimum progression risk, among ùíú, the acceptable set of doses: (2)dŒΩ=argmindj‚ààùíúp2j with p2j, the probability of disease progression at time t‚àó for dose level j.

sec.title: Survival model
sec.p: Given the setting described above, we use a competing risks framework25, 26 to model the probabilities of DLT and disease progression. Let T denote the time‚Äêto‚Äêfailure and k the cause of failure, with k=1 for DLT and k=2 for disease progression. We define Œªkj(t|xkj,Œ≤k), the cause‚Äêspecific instantaneous, and Œõkj(t|xkj,Œ≤k), the cumulative hazards of cause k at dose level j, with xkj, the scaled dose obtained by substituting the initial guess of toxicity and progression probabilities.

We model both competing event processes with exponential hazard distributions.27, 28 Specifically, we assume the cause‚Äêspecific hazard for DLT Œª1j(.) is an increasing function of the dose: (3)Œª1j(t|x1j,Œ≤1)=Œª1j=exp(x1j√óexp(Œ≤1)),forj‚àà{1,‚Ä¶,m}, and define the cause‚Äêspecific hazard for progression Œª2j(.) resulting in a decreasing function of the dose, as follows: (4)Œª2j(t|x2j,Œ≤2)=Œª2j=exp(‚àíx2j√óexp(Œ≤2)),forj‚àà{1,‚Ä¶,m}, where Œ≤1 and Œ≤2 are model parameters of the dose‚Äêtoxicity and dose‚Äêprogression relationships, respectively.

Fkj(¬∑), the cumulative incidence of event k, at time t for dose level j, that is, the subdistribution function depending on both DLT and progression, expresses the probability of failing from cause k at or before t with dose level j, as follows: (5)Fkj(t,Œª1j,Œª2j)=‚à´0tŒªkj√óS(s)ds=Œªkj√ó(1‚àíexp(‚àí(Œª1j+Œª2j)√ót))Œª1j+Œª2j with S(t)=exp(‚àí(Œõ1(t)+Œõ2(t))), the event‚Äêfree survival, that is, the probability of not having experienced a failure, from any cause (DLT or disease progression), at time t.

Given B=(Œ≤1,Œ≤2) and N included patients, the survival likelihood can be expressed as follows: (6)Ln(C,Y,D|B)=‚àèi=1Nf1(Ci,B,ùíüi)I(Yi=1)f2(Ci,B,ùíüi)I(Yi=2)S(Ci,B,ùíüi)I(Yi=0) with fk the density function of T, the time‚Äêto‚Äêevent k, C the right‚Äêcensored failure time and Y the observed outcome defined as Y=1 when DLT occurs first, Y=2 when disease progression occurs first and Y=0 when neither DLT nor progression occurs within the observation window.

Inference on cause‚Äêspecific hazards could be performed for DLT and disease progression separately, since the log‚Äêlikelihood factors into two pieces, one involving Œª1 and the other involving Œª2.27, 28 Given the set of doses D, the likelihood Ln(Œ≤k|C,Y,D) and normal prior distributions œï(Œ≤k) of Œ≤k, the posterior distributions for Œ≤k for event k using Bayes inference is given by: (7)œï(Œ≤k)(Œ≤k|C,Y,D)‚àùLn(C,Y,D|Œ≤k)œï(Œ≤k).

The posterior mean Œ≤k^ can be plugged in Equations¬†(3) to (5) to compute F^kj(t,Œª1j,Œª2j), the mean estimated cumulative incidence of event k at each dose level j: (8)Œ≤^k=‚à´‚àí‚àû‚àûŒ≤kLn(C,Y,D|Œ≤k)œï(Œ≤k)dŒ≤k‚à´‚àí‚àû‚àûLn(C,Y,D|Œ≤k)Œ¶(Œ≤k)dŒ≤k.
The toxicity and progression cumulative incidence estimates are then used to make decision regarding dose allocation as described in Section¬†3.3.

sec.title: Dose‚Äêfinding algorithm
sec.p: Based on the aforementioned probability model, we propose a one‚Äêstage dose‚Äêfinding trial using both toxicity and efficacy information in the dose‚Äêassignment process with the goal to identify a dose that optimizes the efficacy outcome, that is, the time‚Äêto‚Äêprogression among a set of acceptable doses, ùíúi, as defined below.

The set of good doses, ùí¢i, is then defined as the dose levels among ùíúi with an estimated incidence of progression at time t‚Äâ‚àó, F^2j(t‚àó,Œª1j,Œª2j), lying within a range œµP from the minimum estimate: (10)ùí¢i={dj‚ààùíúi:F^2j(t‚àó,Œª1j,Œª2j)‚àímin(F^2j(t‚àó,Œª1j,Œª2j))‚â§œµP}, where œµP is a fixed known parameter that can be tuned based on clinical considerations related to the risk of progression under the standard of care.

To choose the dose allocated to the upcoming (i+1)th patient (or cohort) among the set of good doses ùí¢i, we use an adaptive randomization algorithm,17 unless only a single good dose level is identified. Otherwise, randomization across those good doses prevents the method from getting ‚Äústuck‚Äù on a single dose that has been tried early in the trial. Based on the estimated cumulative incidence of progression, F^2j(t‚àó,Œª1j,Œª2j), for doses dj‚ààùí¢i, randomization probability Rj is computed as follows: (11)‚Ñõj=1‚àíF^2j(t‚àó,Œª1j,Œª2j)‚àëdj‚ààùí¢i1‚àíF^2j(t‚àó,Œª1j,Œª2j), and is used to allocate the next patient or cohort to dose dj‚ààùí¢i with probability Rj.

The trial ended either when the maximum sample size N has been reached, or for safety decisions, that is, when the posterior probability of F11(t‚ãÜ|d1) exceeding the target œÄDLT is at least 0.95.29 In the latter, we consider all doses as over‚Äêtoxic and terminate the trial. If the maximum sample size N has been reached and the follow‚Äêup completed for every patient, the OD, dŒΩ^, is then estimated as the dose with the minimum estimated cumulative incidence of progression among the acceptable set of doses, ùíúN‚àó: (12)dŒΩ^=argmindj‚ààùíúN‚àóF^2j(t‚àó,Œª1j,Œª2j).

An optional preliminary stage centered on the dose‚Äêtoxicity relationship could also be conducted before the optimization presented above if clinical considerations justify increased caution related to patients safety at the beginning of the trial. More precisely, we propose to first use a continual reassessment method (CRM)‚Äêlike approach, in order to guide sequential dose‚Äêassignments of the first subset of r√óN patients of the total sample size N, with r‚àà[0,1] a design parameter to be pre‚Äêspecified when planning the trial. Relying on the monotonicity assumption of the dose‚Äêtoxicity relationship, the objective of this first stage is to identify the dose with a cumulative incidence of DLT at time t‚Äâ‚àó, F1j(¬∑), closest to a pre‚Äêspecified target œÄDLT. At this stage, an upcoming (i+1)th cohort of patients is therefore allocated to dose dji+1 in the following way: (13)dji+1=argmindj‚ààùíü|F^1j(t‚àó,Œª1j,Œª2j)‚àíœÄDLT|.
After the rN patients have been included, we incorporate information on the dose‚Äêprogression relationship in the dose‚Äêassignment process as presented above.

sec.title: SIMULATION STUDY
sec.p: We conducted a comprehensive simulation study to explore the properties of our proposed Surv‚ÄêCRM‚Äê12 design across a variety of settings. The operating characteristics of the Surv‚ÄêCRM‚Äê12 design were compared with that of the TITE‚ÄêBOIN‚ÄêET22 approach. Indeed, the objective of the TITE‚ÄêBOIN‚ÄêET is also to determine the OD defined as the dose that maximizes the efficacy probability satisfying a tolerability constraint. Additionally, performances of the proposed design were assessed using a nonparametric benchmark approach.30, 31

sec.title: Setting
sec.p: In line with our motivating example, we set the observation window t‚àó=42 days. We considered J=5 candidate dose levels, and, within the time window t‚àó, a target toxicity probability of DLT at œÄDLT=0.25 and a threshold to define the good doses, œµP=0.10. We simulated patient accrual using a Poisson process with an expected accrual rate of 4 patients in 42 days. The total sample size was set at N=45 using a single stage design for dose assignment (ie, rN=0). Simulated trials were initiated with the first dose level, d1. The cohort size was 1, and no dose skipping was allowed.

To assess the robustness of our proposed method, sensitivity analyses were also conducted. We first conducted a simulation study to examine the sensitivity of our design to the specification of priors. We considered normal priors with different SDs for the unknown parameters Œ≤1 and Œ≤2 under each scenarios. We also varied the sample size from N=30 to N=150, and the number of patients allocated to the first optional toxicity‚Äêcentered stage, r=0.33 and r=0.5. Furthermore, we also evaluated our method in the case of correlated time‚Äêto‚Äêevent data using the Clayton model following Yuan and Yin's approach.16

sec.title: Calibration of model parameters
sec.p: To jointly calibrate the skeletons and the prior variance of the parameters Œ≤1 and Œ≤2, we extended the calibration procedure using the concepts of the least informative prior variance and indifference intervals developed by Lee and Cheung.32 Specifically, two design skeletons, for toxicity and progression respectively, were calibrated using the indifference interval approach,33, 34 using the working models of the proposed design (Equation¬†5).

Let Œ∏DLT be the target probability of toxicity and Œ∏PROG the expected probability of progression at the best guess or expected OD dŒΩ, at t‚àó. Let Œòk=[bk1,bkJ+1] be the parameter space for the working model of event k (ie, bk‚ààŒòk with k=1 for toxicity and k=2 for progression). We define the indifference intervals for event k, ‚Ñãk1=[bk1,bk2), ‚Ñãkj=(bkj,bkj+1) for j=2,‚Ä¶,J‚àí1 and ‚ÑãkJ=(bkJ,bkJ+1], where Bj=(b1j,b2j) solves Fkj(t‚àó,Xj‚àí1;Bj)+Fkj(t‚àó,Xj;Bj)=2Œ∏DLTfork=12Œ∏PROGfork=2 with Xj=(x1j,x2j) the scaled doses.

By specifying a common half‚Äêwidth indifference interval for all dose levels, that is Œ¥, X1,‚Ä¶XJ can be obtained recursively using the approach presented in Lee and Cheung,33 as described below. x1j‚àí1=log‚àílog{1‚àí(Œ∏DLT‚àíŒ¥)‚àí(Œ∏PROG+Œ¥)}(1+Œ∏PROG+Œ¥Œ∏DLT‚àíŒ¥)√ót‚àó√ó1exp(b1j),x2j‚àí1=‚àílog(Œ∏PROG+Œ¥)√óexp(exp(b1j)√óx1j‚àí1)Œ∏DLT‚àíŒ¥√ó1exp(b2j), for j=2,‚Ä¶,ŒΩ, x1j+1=log‚àílog{1‚àí(Œ∏DLT+Œ¥)‚àí(Œ∏PROG‚àíŒ¥)}(1+Œ∏PROG‚àíŒ¥Œ∏DLT+Œ¥)√ót‚àó√ó1exp(b1j+1),x2j+1=‚àílog(Œ∏PROG‚àíŒ¥)√óexp(exp(b1j+1)√óx1j+1)Œ∏DLT+Œ¥√ó1exp(b2j+1), for j=ŒΩ,‚Ä¶,J‚àí1.

Then, the least informative prior normal SD for Œ≤1, œÉŒ≤1LI, can be obtained for a given Œ¥ using the toxicity working model with the least informative prior approach described in Lee and Cheung.32 The least informative SD is the one such that the prior probability of selecting a dose corresponds to a uniform distribution among the candidate dose levels (ie, 1/J). We assume the prior normal SD for Œ≤2 is equal to the SD of Œ≤1.

Based on this approach, we calibrated both skeletons (toxicity and progression) and the prior variance for the working models parameters, Œ≤1 and Œ≤2, in our trial setting. We first evaluated the performances of the Surv‚ÄêCRM‚Äê12 across values of Œ¥ based on a set of calibration scenarios where the true probabilities of DLT and progression followed plateau configurations as described by Lee and Cheung.33 The algorithm was implemented with t‚àó=42, a target toxicity probability Œ∏DLT=0.25 and an expected progression probability Œ∏PROG=0.40 at dŒΩ, J=5 dose levels and dose level 3 as the OD. We iterated Œ¥ from 0.01 to 0.6Œ∏DLT in a discrete domain with a grid half‚Äêwidth of 0.01 and calculate œÉŒ≤1LI for each Œ¥ value. Based on 2000 simulations, on a set of calibration scenarios of the plateau configuration defined following,33 we set the half‚Äêwidth of the indifference interval at 0.07 and the prior SD at 0.379, as providing the highest average probability of correct selection (PCS) across the calibration scenarios, corresponding to the following skeletons for toxicity and progression respectively {0.055, 0.130, 0.250, 0.406, 0.571} and {0.666, 0.541, 0.400, 0.266, 0.158}. As a sensitivity analysis, we also considered fixing the SD at 1.34 35 and only calibrating the two skeletons using the indifference interval approach.

sec.title: Simulated scenarios
sec.p: Several non‚Äêparametric scenarios of dose‚Äêtoxicity and dose‚Äêprogression relationships were examined (Figure¬†1). They differed in terms of the cumulative incidences of DLT and disease progression at time t‚ãÜ by dose level and encompassed different realistic shapes of dose‚ÄêDLT and dose‚Äêprogression relationships.

caption.p: Simulation scenarios: True cumulative incidences of DLT (solid line) and progression (dashed line) at time t‚àó for each dose level, D1 to D5. OD, optimal dose

sec.p: The first seven scenarios (Sc) had varying optimal and acceptable doses in position over the range of the five candidate dose levels: for Sc1 to Sc3, Sc6, Sc9, and Sc11, acceptable doses were d1 to d3; for Sc4, Sc7, and Sc8, d1 to d4, and for Sc5 and Sc10, d1 to d5. Scenarios also differed regarding the shape of dose‚Äêprogression relationships including high (Sc9‚ÄêSc11), low (Sc2) and moderate risk of disease progression, steeper slope (Sc1‚ÄêSc5) and plateau (Sc6 and Sc7). We also examined operating characteristics of our proposed design in comparison with the benchmark approach and the TITE‚ÄêBOIN‚ÄêET design on a U‚Äêshape dose‚Äêprogression scenario (Sc8). To avoid cherry‚Äêpicked scenarios that favor the proposed design, we examined four additional scenarios previously used in the study by Takeda et al22 (Sc9‚ÄêSc12). For simplicity, we defined the true cumulative incidence of progression at time t‚àó as the complementary of the true probability of efficacy.

Trial data were generated according to a tolerance profile procedure30, 31 drawn from a uniform distribution ùïå(0,1) summarizing patient's toxicity and progression outcomes. Instantaneous cause‚Äêspecific hazards of both events, (Œª1andŒª2) were back computed from cumulative incidence values of event assumed at time t‚àó at each dose level, using exponentially distributed event times. Competing risks data were then simulated following Beyersmann et al's approach.36 Observations were sampled from an exponential model for the time‚Äêto‚Äêfirst event T (event‚Äêfree survival), with all‚Äêcause hazard (Œª1+Œª2) and the cause of failure determined by a random draw from a Bernoulli distribution with probability Œª1Œª1+Œª2 for toxicity (otherwise disease progression). Last, administrative censoring was applied at time t‚àó to mimic the trial observation window. For trials generated under the Clayton model for time‚Äêto‚Äêevent data, details are available in the Supporting Web Materials.

sec.title: Comparative methods
sec.p: To evaluate performances of our proposed design, we developed a nonparametric benchmark approach providing an upper bound estimate on selecting the OD under a given scenario, and at a fixed sample size.12, 30, 31 We revised the benchmark approach proposed by Cheung31 for complex designs with a bivariate dose‚Äêfinding objective, to account for right‚Äêcensored endpoints and competing risks events. These benchmark values for dose selection provide meaningful information on the complexity of scenario in terms of OD identification and provide a reference for the performance of a dose‚Äêfinding algorithm with complete potential information, that is, as if outcomes could be observed at all dose levels for all patients. In our setting of a bivariate dose‚Äêfinding objective relying on the cumulative incidence of DLT and progression, we computed a benchmark based on two endpoints (toxicity and progression).31 In the presence of informative censoring, cumulative incidences were estimated as described by Gray.37 Non parametric estimators for the benchmark were chosen, similarly to the original benchmark proposal for binary endpoints.30 The OD was estimated from the complete dataset based on the trial objective defined in Equation (2). Details of the benchmark approach are provided in Supporting Web Material (Table S1).

For a comparison purpose in dose selection performances, we also applied the TITE‚ÄêBOIN‚ÄêET design22 to the simulation scenarios. With the TITE‚ÄêBOIN‚ÄêET design, the method used to guide dose escalation is different from the method used for final estimation. Briefly, for OD estimation at the end of the trial, regression models for each of the toxicity and efficacy outcomes are fitted. For toxicity, an isotonic regression is performed and for efficacy, a model with fractional polynomials with two degrees of freedom is applied. The OD is then determined as the dose that maximizes the efficacy probability among a set satisfying tolerability, that is, dose levels equal or below the MTD (ie, dose with toxicity probability closest to the target toxicity probability œÄDLT). In our setting, we assumed efficacy when a patient is alive without progression. Thus, the true cumulative incidence of progression at time t‚àó are defined as the complementary of the true probability of efficacy. A set‚Äêup for simulations as close as possible to our simulation setting was used for a fair comparison with respect to the maximum number of patients (N=45), cohort size (=1), starting dose (d1), assessment windows for toxicity and efficacy (42 days) and accrual rate (one patient per 10 days). For dose assignment during the trial, the target toxicity probability and the target efficacy probability were œÄDLT=0.25 and œÄEFF=0.95, respectively. To match the Surv‚ÄêCRM‚Äê12 dose‚Äêfinding objective of minimizing time‚Äêto‚Äêprogression, which corresponds to maximizing the efficacy probability in the TITE‚ÄêBOIN‚ÄêET setting, we chose to set a target efficacy probability, œÄEFF, close to 100%. We set the highest acceptable toxicity probability œÄ1 DLT=0.4œÄDLT (ie, 60% deviation from the target), the lowest DLT probability that is overly toxic œÄ2 DLT=1.4œÄDLT, (ie, 40% deviation from the target), and the highest efficacy probability that is subtherapeutic œÄ1 EFF=0.6œÄEFF (ie, 40% deviation from the target). As a result, the optimal values of the lower and upper cutoffs on toxicity and the cutoff on efficacy were estimated to be {0.21;0.29;0.80}. We defined safety decisions as close as possible to our setting. Skipping dose(s) was not allowed. Early termination criteria were set as follows: when posterior probability of efficacy was less than 0.05 (ie, 1‚àíœÄEFF) was above 0.95, or the posterior probability of toxicity was above 0.25 (ie, œÄDLT) was above 0.95, the dose was removed. If all doses were removed, the dose‚Äêfinding trial was terminated. An early termination rule was applied based on at least 3 patients enrolled in a trial.

All the simulations were based on 10¬†000 replicates for the Surv‚ÄêCRM‚Äê12 and TITE‚ÄêBOIN‚ÄêET designs, and benchmark. For each scenario, we computed the percentage of times that each of the designs selected each dose level as the final OD, percentage of early trial stopping for safety decisions (P‚Äâstop), the average overdose number (No. OV), defined as the average number of patients treated at a dose above the true OD during the trial,38 the average number of patients that experienced DLT (No. DLT) and disease progression (No. Prog), and the average number of patients treated at the true OD (No. OD).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Table¬†1 summarizes the simulation results with a total sample size of 45 patients. As expected, the performance of the methods depended on the scenario. The highest percents of correct selection (PCS) reached by the benchmark, 91% and 97%, were observed in scenarios with more than one OD due to a plateau shape of the dose‚Äêprogression relationship (Sc6 and Sc7, respectively). Performances of the proposed Surv‚ÄêCRM‚Äê12 design were in line with these findings, as highest PCS, 91% and 93%, were reached for Sc6 and Sc7 respectively. On the other hand, the Surv‚ÄêCRM‚Äê12 selected the relatively higher dose levels as the ODs even if the risks of toxicity were increased but acceptable among the dose levels when the risks of disease progression were the same. In scenarios with moderate risk of disease progression and monotone decreasing dose‚Äêprogression (Sc1 to Sc5), the Surv‚ÄêCRM‚Äê12 correctly selected the OD in more than 60% of cases and outperformed the TITE‚ÄêBOIN‚ÄêET method. The Surv‚ÄêCRM‚Äê12 seemed robust to different dose‚Äêprogression relationships given a fixed risk of toxicity. Indeed, for Sc1 to Sc3, with the same dose‚Äêtoxicity relationship and different flat dose‚Äêprogression relationships, the Surv‚ÄêCRM‚Äê12 provided a satisfactory PCS greater than or equal to 71% and outperformed the benchmark with PCS fluctuating between 52% and 70%. In scenarios with OD at extreme dose levels (Sc5 and Sc12), the Surv‚ÄêCRM‚Äê12 picked the OD in 64% and 66% of cases respectively, contrary to 76% and 90% with the benchmark. As expected, the lowest PCS, 27%, was observed in the case of a U‚Äêshape progression scenario (Sc8), while the PCS with the non‚Äêparametric TITE‚ÄêBOIN‚ÄêET was 51%, and 80% with the benchmark. Finally, with huge risks of progression, 95% for the first dose level (Sc9, Sc10), the Surv‚ÄêCRM‚Äê12 and the TITE‚ÄêBOIN‚ÄêET hesitated between the correct dose level and the one above: PCS were 55% and 48% with the Surv‚ÄêCRM‚Äê12 for Sc9 and Sc10 respectively, slightly higher than the TITE‚ÄêBOIN‚ÄêET (PCS of 43% and 34% respectively), while the PCS with the benchmark were 47% and 69% respectively. To conclude in terms of picking the correct dose, the Surv‚ÄêCRM‚Äê12 outperformed the TITE‚ÄêBOIN‚ÄêET method over all scenarios except in the case of a U‚Äêshape dose‚Äêprogression relationship.

caption.p: Simulation results for Sc1 to Sc6 of the Surv‚ÄêCRM‚Äê12 design, TITE‚ÄêBOIN‚ÄêET and benchmark; percent of stopped trials for safety (P‚Äâstop); percent of selection; number of overdose (No. OV); number of observed DLT (No. DLT); number of observed progression (No. Prog) and number of patients treated with the true OD (No. OD) during the trial

tr.th: Percent of selection by dose level (%)

fn.p: Note: 10¬†000 simulated trials (Surv‚ÄêCRM‚Äê12 design and benchmark) with N=45, œÄDLT=0.25 and œµP=0.1. 10¬†000 simulated trials (TITE‚ÄêBOIN‚ÄêET) with œÄDLT=0.25, œÄEFF=0.95, œÄ1 DLT=0.4,œÄDLT, œÄ2 DLT=1.4œÄDLT and œÄ1 EFF=0.6œÄEFF. Correct selection results based on ODs are given in boldface.

sec.p: In terms of patient exposure during the trial over the 12 scenarios, the mean number of patients allocated to overdoses (OV) was 10.19 out of a total sample size of 45 patients with the Surv‚ÄêCRM‚Äê12 design, below the 14.08 mean value observed with the TITE‚ÄêBOIN‚ÄêET. However, fewer patients experienced DLT during the trial using the TITE‚ÄêBOIN‚ÄêET: the average number of DLT over all scenarios was 8.73 vs 10.14 with Surv‚ÄêCRM‚Äê12. Finally, for 11 out of the 12 scenarios, the average number of patients treated at the true OD was higher with the Surv‚ÄêCRM‚Äê12 design and the average OD over all scenarios was 24.95 against 17.88 with the TITE‚ÄêBOIN‚ÄêET.

As shown by Lee and Cheung,32 having a larger prior variance changes the distribution of the prior probability of dose selection from uniform to U‚Äêshaped, leading in higher chances of extreme doses selections. Indeed, with SD equal to 1.34, PCS was higher for Sc5 with OD at level 5, equal to 75%. For Sc12, with OD in dose level 1, PCS was lower with SD equal to 1.34, equal to 59% but the percent of stopped trial for safety decision was much higher (equal to 18% contrary to 4% with the least informative SD) (Table S2 in Supporting Web Materials).

Expectedly, the performances of all three compared designs improved with increasing sample sizes (Figure S2, Supporting Web Materials). Moreover, the impact of the sample size of the optional first stage was limited (Table S3, Supporting Web Materials), so that this could be left to clinicians' preference.

Finally, sensitivity simulations showed that the performance of the Surv‚ÄêCRM‚Äê12 was mostly preserved in case of correlated events. The PCS was maintained under data generated with correlated times to toxicity and progression, but the POS increased; similar results were observed with the benchmark (Figure S3, Supporting Web Materials).

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: In this article, we proposed a novel one‚Äêstage Bayesian adaptive phase I/II design, named the Survival‚ÄêCRM‚Äê12, for novel anti‚Äêcancer drugs such as immunotherapies and MTAs, with the purpose to identify the OD defined as the dose with acceptable risk of toxicity and a minimum risk of disease progression. Such a targeted dose, sometimes called the ‚Äúbest‚Äù dose17 appeared suitable for such early phase I/II trials, with the aim of maximizing the likelihood of efficacy while only ensuring safety constrains. Our proposed design allows continuous enrollment of patients, and handles competing risks, including the information of time‚Äêto‚Äêevent outcomes using survival working models for right‚Äêcensored endpoints. It allows the toxicity outcome to be delayed or unobserved due to competing progression within the observation window. Such an issue of late‚Äêonset outcome is common and important in the field of novel anticancer agents. Indeed, it has been reported that 57% of the grades 3‚Äê4 toxicities occur after the treatment cycle 1 in 36 clinical trials of molecularly targeted agents.39 Moreover, disease progression is one of the main cause of premature discontinuation from a Phase I trial (approximately 70% of cases),40 and should be managed other than by ad‚Äêhoc strategies of replacing patients. As demonstrated in the simulation study across a variety of realistic scenarios, and assessed by the benchmark, our proposed method appears an interesting approach in this setting, exhibiting desirable operating characteristics. Indeed, our design performs well in selecting the OD, as well as treating patient at safe doses during the clinical trial.

Studies have examined the impact of model specification on the performance of the dose‚Äêfinding design and have shown the importance of selecting appropriate model parameters via simulation studies.41, 42 Instead of arbitrarily setting initial guesses of the probabilities of DLT and disease progression, and prior variance for model parameters, we proposed a systematic calibration process based on previous literature.32, 33 The calibration method which used jointly the half‚Äêwidth of the indifference interval both for the toxicity and progression working models, and the least informative prior variance had satisfactory operating characteristics. Jointly calibrating the initial guesses of the probabilities of toxicity and progression at each dose and the prior variance, simplified the calibration process as it reduced the number of parameters to be specified. This approach makes the Bayesian Surv‚ÄêCRM‚Äê12 model‚Äêbased design more accessible and easier to implement.

In this phase I/II setting, we chose to model disease progression instead of efficacy, highlighting its competition with the observation of toxicities. Indeed, unlike conventional chemotherapy that works by shrinking the tumor, immunotherapeutic agents often delay cancer progression and prolong survival without achieving rapid tumor shrinkage, and a certain percentage of patients who receive immunotherapy often achieve a long‚Äêterm durable response.43 Therefore, for some early phase immunotherapeutic trials, it is preferable to use as efficacy criterion the disease progression, rather than the conventional treatment response. Recently, Zhang et al44 developed a dose finding phase I/II design accounting for the late‚Äêonset competing risk endpoint, relying on piecewise cause‚Äêspecific hazard to characterize the competing risk outcomes. However, it treats late‚Äêonset outcomes as missing data while we incorporated them in our model, and requires the definition of a utility function for identifying the OD.

This study has some limitations. First, we modeled the cause‚Äêspecific hazard for progression as a decreasing function of dose. Although a model‚Äêbased approach allows the borrowing of information across dose levels, a potential limitation related to this choice of working model is that the Surv‚ÄêCRM‚Äê12 tends to select higher doses among safe doses in cases of plateau scenarios for dose‚Äêprogression relationship and it does not perform well for U‚Äêshaped dose‚Äêprogression relationships. Nonparametric approaches which do not rely on any assumption on the dose‚Äêtoxicity and dose‚Äêefficacy curves, may be useful in those situations,45 as the TITE‚ÄêBOIN‚ÄêET approach proposed. This approach is part of the model‚Äêassisted designs as its decision rule can be predetermined, but requires specification during the trial planning of several cutoffs by the clinician. A nonparametric approach was also considered with the benchmark method using the complete profiles of outcomes under all dose levels instead of the time‚Äêto‚Äêevent outcome under the assigned dose in the Surv‚ÄêCRM‚Äê12 or TITE‚ÄêBOIN‚ÄêET designs. Nevertheless, the Surv‚ÄêCRM‚Äê12 model‚Äêbased design outperformed the benchmark in some scenarios, which is not observed with the TITE‚ÄêBOIN‚ÄêET model‚Äêassisted design. In sparse settings such as phase I/II clinical, parametric working models may outperform the non‚Äêparametric benchmark in capturing the dose‚Äêresponse relationships since they allow sharing information across dose levels.38 Second, the ‚Äúoptimal‚Äù dose level could have been defined as the dose with both the highest probability of efficacy and the lowest probability of toxicity. This could be the target in particularly frail populations, for example, in neonates and children. However, this assumes equal weighting of toxicity and efficacy, and at the time, the growing accelerated approvals of drugs, notably in oncology, suggests that the target of interest is mostly efficacy.46 Nevertheless, we agree that some consensus regarding the target dose in such trials, should be reached in the future. This would allow a more relevant comparison of all the proposed designs.

Finally, with the emergence of anti‚Äêcancer molecularly‚Äêtargeted agents and immunotherapy agents changing the landscape of dose‚Äêfinding in oncology, it is essential to incorporate both late‚Äêonset toxicities and progression information which are often collected as mutually exclusive events into the identification of OD. The proposed phase I/II Surv‚ÄêCRM‚Äê12 design achieved the best performance in selecting the OD and allocating patients to the OD when trial discontinuation after disease progression within the observation window is likely to preclude the observation of DLTs in a non‚Äênegligible proportion of patients. It should be considered when designing dose‚Äêfinding trials of targeted therapies with prolonged observation windows in advanced cancer patients where treatment discontinuations due to disease progression are likely to occur.

sec.title: CONFLICT OF INTEREST
sec.p: The authors declare no potential conflict of interests.

sec.title: DATA AVAILABILITY STATEMENT
sec.p: Data sharing not applicable to this article as no datasets were generated or analyzed during the current study.
